content:
EXISTING STRUCTURES
────────────────────────
### Stone Furnace Facility at (0.0, 0.0)
Consists of:
– Stone Furnace at (0.0, 0.0)  
– Iron Chest at (1.5, 0.5)  
Use-case: Primary smelting station for converting raw materials into iron plates.

### Iron Ore Mining Setup at (–16.0, –51.0)
Consists of:
– Burner Mining Drill at (–16.0, –51.0)  
– Burner Inserter at (–14.5, –49.5)  
– Iron Chest at (–13.5, –49.5)  
– Burner Inserter at (–14.5, –47.5)  
– Fast Inserter at (–12.5, –49.5)  
– Fast Inserter at (–13.5, –45.5)  
Use-case: Extraction and initial transport of iron ore for further processing.

### Copper Furnace at (–27.0, –60.0)
Consists of:
– Furnace at (–27.0, –60.0)  
Use-case: Processes copper ore into copper plates for advanced manufacturing.

### Lab Power Integration System at (0.5, 2.5)
Consists of:
– Lab at (0.5, 2.5)  
– Offshore Pump at (–7.5, 25.5)  
– Offshore Pump at (–9.5, 24.5)  
– Repositioned Boiler at (–13.0, 26.5) with rotated orientation (connection point at (–13.5, 24.5))  
– Steam Engine at (11.5, 27.5) (currently producing no power)  
Use-case: Supports lab operations through integrated power and fluid systems; recent adjustments to the Boiler’s position and orientation aim to establish a valid fluid connection with the Offshore Pump, yet water flow and steam generation remain unestablished.

### Copper Cable Factory at (2.5, 6.5)
Consists of:
– Repositioned Assembling Machine at (2.5, 6.5) configured for the Copper Cable recipe (status: NO_POWER)  
– Pre-existing Small Electric Pole at (4.5, 6.5) serving as a local power node  
– Stone Furnace at (7.0, 11.0) for smelting Copper Ore into Copper Plates  
– Additional Small Electric Pole at (2.5, 3.5) placed using direction UP (spacing 1)  
– Additional Small Electric Pole at (2.5, 8.5) placed using direction DOWN (spacing 0)  
– Intermediate Small Electric Pole at (8.5, 18.5) manually placed to bridge the connection between the Steam Engine and the Assembling Machine  
– Fallback Small Electric Pole at (0.5, 6.5) placed adjacent to the Assembling Machine  
– Steam Engine at (11.5, 27.5) connected via multiple chain attempts (currently producing no power)  
Use-case: Produces Copper Cables from smelted Copper Plates; persistent power network issues remain despite multiple connection enhancements.

### Fluid Pipelines (Multiple Pipe Groups)
Consists of:
– Multiple PipeGroups spanning positions such as (–10.5, 22.5) to (–9.5, 23.5); additional groups at (8.5, 5.5), (10.5, 4.5), (–9.5, 24.5) (to the Boiler), (2.5, 9.5), (10.5, 9.5), (1.5, 11.5), (–1.5, 17.5), (0.5, 17.5), (6.5, 16.5), (–1.5, 21.5) and (4.5, 25.5)  
Use-case: Transports fluids between production components; connectivity challenges persist between the Boiler and the Steam Engine.

### Integrated Components
Consists of:
– BeltGroup connecting inserter and belt outputs  
– Electricity network via multiple ElectricityGroups with poles at positions such as [(-10.5, -49.5), (-12.5, -48.5), (-12.5, -50.5)], near (3.5, 0.5), [(6.5, 3.5), (5.5, 8.5)] and [(2.5, 30.5), (7.5, 26.5)]  
Use-case: Provides overall material handling and supports factory operations with an extensive power network.

ERROR TIPS
────────────────────────
• Crafting and Resource Management  
 – Crafting Ingredient Shortages: Ensure that all required sub-ingredients (e.g., copper-cable, wood) are available before commencing any crafting.  
 – Offshore Pump and Electronic Component Crafting Failures: Confirm the availability of raw resources and sub-ingredients to prevent crafting interruptions.

• Entity Placement and Buildable Area  
 – Entity Placement and Collision Issues: Verify that all target tiles are clear of existing entities before placement; adjust spacing or orientation as necessary.  
 – Repositioning and Buildable Area Computation Errors: Validate that computed buildable areas fall within permissible boundaries to avoid out-of-range placements.  
 – Pipe Placement Obstruction Errors: Check that designated pipe locations are unobstructed before attempting placement.

• Power Network and Connectivity  
 – Power Network Connection Errors: Ensure that power chains are continuous and that connected entities (e.g., the Steam Engine and Assembling Machine) receive adequate input; verify inventory requirements prior to establishing connections.  
 – Persistent Power and Fluid Flow Issues: Reassess fluid routing and pipeline alignment to facilitate proper water flow into the Boiler, enabling steam generation and restoring power to production components.

• Fluid Connection and Pipe Routing  
 – Fluid Connection Failures: Confirm that fluid source and target connection points are unobstructed and within valid transfer range.  
 – Fluid Connection Alignment and Interface Errors: Align connection points accurately—for example, verify that the Boiler’s connection point at (–13.5, 24.5) aligns with the Offshore Pump at (–9.5, 24.5); reposition and rotate components as needed.  
 – Manual Pipe Chain and Two-Step Connection Failures: When using intermediate points, ensure that the chosen coordinates are valid, unobstructed, and fall within the fluid system’s connectivity range.

• Function and Type Handling  
 – Function and Type Usage Errors: Initialize all variables properly and use object properties correctly to avoid runtime type issues.

• Inventory and Operation Management  
 – Resource Insertion and Availability Issues: Verify inventory stock before attempting placement operations; replenish supplies as necessary.  
 – Fuel and Resource Insertion Issues: Monitor essential inputs such as boiler fuel and ensure timely replenishment.  
 – Component Extraction and Removal Operation Errors: Ensure that production cycles are complete and that entities exist with correct data types prior to extraction or removal operations.
